description:
Bitcoinopoly is a highly strategic crypto-powered version of the Wall Street trading floor. Players take turns drawing and playing cards until someone collects three colour coded sets of crypto currencies and lays them out on the table.

Players pick up cards and attempt to collect 3 matching sets.  The  first play to do so wins.  However, event cards can stop your efforts!

The game becomes increasingly intense as each player builds their crypto portfolio, as each player's crypto trading strategy becomes apparent. This is when you'll have to use all your strategic might. GOOD LUCK!

Wayfarers of the South Tigris is set during the height of the Abbasid Caliphate, circa 820 AD. As brave explorers, cartographers and astronomers, players set off from Baghdad to map the surrounding land, waterways, and heavens above. Players must carefully manage their caravan of workers and equipment, while reporting back regularly to journal their findings at the House of Wisdom. Will you succeed in impressing the Caliph, or lose your way and succumb to the wilderness?

The aim of Wayfarers of the South Tigris is to be the player with the most victory points (VP) at the game's end. Points are primarily gained by mapping the land, water, and sky. Players can also gain points from upgrading their caravans, by gaining inspiration from nobles, and by influencing the three guilds of science, trade and exploration. As they make discoveries, players will want to quickly journal their progress. The game ends once one player’s marker has reached the far right column of the journal track.

—description from the publisher

A reverse-trivia game for adults that uses a smart assistant (Google, Alexa, Siri, etc). Pick a card from 4 categories in play and get the smart assistant to say the word or name on the card while following a set of rules of things you can not do. The base game comes with 10 categories with 36 game cards in each as well as a 36 card cheat deck.

4 categories are chosen at random. 6 Game cards from each chosen category are stacked below each matching category card. Play starts in the clockwise rotation. The player chooses a category and then selects the top card from its deck. They must now get the SA to say the word or name on the card, without saying it and by following other rules such as - no spelling, no present or past tense versions of the word etc.

When the 24 game cards are gone, the game is over, and the person with the most wins. Easy right?

In this game, players battle each other by showing one number card out of three open cards in their hands.

The higher the number card is, the higher points you will get, but it becomes easier for your opponent to read your card, and harder for you to win.

The lower the number card is, the easier you will win, but the lower points you will get.

It is important to judge when to attack and when to defend.

This is a psychological game, where the decisive factors are reading, bargaining, and intuition.

—description from the designer

Each player/team has their own deck of 25 cards. The entire alphabet is comprised by 22 of them. Four cards show two letters, either of which can be used. The remaining 3 cards are special cards.

On a turn all players flip over their top card and thinks of a word that begins with that letter and is equal to the number of letters on the first square of their flight path on the game board. Play continues in real time until a player has reached Madswatter (finish space).

The winner receives 10 points. Penalties includes spaces left by the longest path and errors (-5 pts each).

Three matches are played and the winner is the player with the most points.

Animal spirits are building a new world by plucking floating pieces of land from the sky and stitching them together with mystical thread. These powerful spirits are the World Stitchers, and even though they are working together to create a new world, only one of them will have the honor of naming it.

Play as one of the animal spirits in this modular, competitive tile-laying game for 1-4 players. Expand the world, gather the energy that's released when new pieces of land are connected, and raise massive natural spires from the ground to impress the other spirits.

World Stitchers is very easy to teach and quick to set up. The game comes with several interchangeable modules to add complexity and variety as you see fit.

—description from the publisher

The game recreates Napoleon’s efforts to capture Berlin in the summer of 1813 and knock the Prussians out of the Sixth Coalition. The game includes three different major battles: Blankenfeld; Gross Beeren; and Dennewitz which pit the Prussians under Prince Von Bulow and their Russian and Swedish allies against the French Imperial forces under first Marshal Oudinot and then Marshal Ney. Each battle has roughly 60,000-80,000 per side, as the French stretch their multi-national forces to knock the Coalition armies, infused with large numbers of patriotic Landwehr, out of what was to be called the War of Liberation

The package also includes the bonus game, La Bataille de Hagelberg 1813, ME’s previously free print and play game, with a professionally produced map and counters for the first time.

The entire package has over 600 counters; eight maps; and access to ME’s an over 100-page book with Premier rules; extensive special rules; and multiple historical articles; and many charts and other play-aids.

It has been months since the Coven’s Supreme Witch disappeared from Salem Slot village without leaving a trace. The haughtiness and impatience of the novice witches make them compete for the position of the new Supreme Witch. Who will have the greatest power to summon the Dark Lord during the Full Moon nights?

This game simulates the mechanics of slot machines. The objective of the game will be to get combinations of cards by following the panel of game prizes, similar to the slot machines ones and represented in game cards that can be consulted at any moment.

In this game there are 6 different types of moon cards. Each player will draw one card of each type from the so-called "moon phases" (the first 5) and will receive 3 Treat Coins that are used to pay for card exchanges. "Wild" cards will also appear. These will give a certain strategic advantage to the players.

When a player finishes his exchanges (there are two types of exchanges called "trick and treat") he/she must decide if he wants to risk the combination of cards obtained by taking (or not) a card from the sixth moon deck (the “Red Moon”). Here the risk is double or nothing.

The player with the highest score combination will receive a Victory Coin. After winning a second time the player will flip his Victory Coin. And after winning a third time, the game is over.

—description from the designer

We, the Faceless is a fast playing asymmetrical 4x game.

The Faceless Lords, demigods of torment, march their forces into populations centers, reaping skulls and spreading destruction. Clashing with each other, they devastate the landscape, but the dark magic of the faceless lords seal the gods out of the realm, but also seal in the souls of the slain. Some of these souls come back as the Grieved to fight the Faceless beyond death.

Players select control a Faceless Lord, possessing a dark host of unique powers and minions. They choose a Realm to war over, and set up hex tiles according to a Realm map.

Each round, players draft commands from a shared deck, then reveal cards simultaneously; the card's initiative decides the order of actions. Actions include: Marching minions into settlements, reaping skulls & causing destruction, empowering your minions, and casting spells.

As you devastate the realm you gain Hate, until a player triggers their unique End Times, signaling the last round. At the end of the final round the player with the most Hate wins the game, and overtaking the realm.

On a planet of lava and ocean, steam shrouds the terrain as mighty mechanical constructs battle each other for sovereignty. Anachronistic aesthetics and wicked machine designs bring the game to life.

Planes Battle Buildings is a 2 to 4 player miniature strategic game. Each player controls a faction of miniature planes or walking buildings.

Players then draw terrain hex cards to reveal and traverse the unknown landscape. The aim is for each player to gain area control, retain enough resources to maintain and expand their collection of planes or buildings. Conflict arises when players battle over terrain or attempt to pilfer the other player's resources.

Game play is either skirmish mode (where one players wins all) or adventure mode where a scenario is chosen with its own unique set of rules for the players to follow.

2 to 6 Players
Dice Management - Combat - Competitive - Dungeon Crawler

A group of heroes are hired to venture into a labyrinthine and narrow cave near the kingdom, lair of beasts creatures to complete the mission at the risk of being trapped. One player will handle the creatures, the rest will be the heroes.

The players, including the "boss" player, each turn must throw their dice, with them they will be able to pay for the actions during it.

The cave of the route will be revealed in a random way with the movement of the heroes, with a continuity of terrain cards, but the "boss" can lengthen his path.

There are three possible contracts that the heroes must fulfill, when doing so the heroes will win, otherwise the "boss" player will win.

—description from the designer


2 a 6 Jugadores
Gestión de Dados - Combate - Competitivo - Dungeon Crawler

Un grupo de héroes son contratados para aventurarse en una laberíntica y estrecha cueva cercana al reino, guarida de bestiales criaturas para completar la misión a riesgo de quedar atrapados. Un Jugador manejara las criaturas, el resto serán los héroes.

los jugadores, incluido el jugador "jefe", cada turno deberán arrojar sus dados, con ellos podrán pagar las acciones durante el mismo.

La cueva del recorrido se ira revelando de forma azarosa con el movimiento de los héroes, con una continuidad de cartas de terreno, pero el "jefe", puede ir alargando su camino.

Hay tres contratos posibles que los heroes deberan cumplir, al realizarlo los heroes ganaran, de lo contrario ganara el jugador "jefe".

—description from the designer (Spanish)

Emperor Qin Shi Huang has passed away. To protect him in the afterlife, a great army in the form of statues of faithful warriors must be assembled to stand guard in the Emperor's tomb. You will be among those tasked with building this magnificent army.

In Terracotta Army, you represent talented craftsmen and artists laboring to build the wondrous assembly of statues. During the game, you collect resources, upgrade your workers, and seek favor with the Emperor's advisors. Your goal is to play a crucial role in the process of creating the terracotta army, and your success is measured in victory points (VPs). During the game, you and your fellow players build the army together, but after the fifth round of the game is over, only one of you — the one with the most points — will stand as the winner.

During the game, you place warrior miniatures within the mausoleum, forming groups.  A group's miniatures may belong to multiple players as denoted by the player bases on those miniatures. Multiple separate groups consisting of the same type of miniature may exist within the mausoleum.

You will have many opportunities to score points based on domination and presence. To achieve domination, you must be the only player with the most of the specific resource or type of statue currently being scored. (If you are the only player, you have domination.) To have presence, you must have at least one of the specific resource or type of statue currently being scored.

At the end of the fifth round, the player with the most VPs wins.

9-minute Kingdom – A game that takes 9 or fewer minutes to play!
The goal of the game is to build the kingdom for which we get the most points. The players collect points in two ways: by completing the edicts and by connecting the various icons in their kingdoms.
The game is divided into 9 turns during which the players perform actions simultaneously. The players simultaneously pick one card and play it on the table. Next, they pass the unused cards to the player on the left. Using the received cards, the players play another card and add it to their kingdoms. The game continues to the moment of playing the ninth, final card.
Each played card makes your kingdom grow. You just have to follow 3 simple rules:

     Apart from the first card, each following card must be placed adjacent to the card which is already on the table.
     Your kingdom has to form 3x3 square.
     The cards can be added freely and don’t have to match the ones already added to the kingdom.


After completing their kingdoms the players go to the scoring phase. Firstly, the players receive the edict cards, starting with the „Kingsroad” edict. It goes to the player with the longest connected road in the kingdom. Next, the rest of the edict cards are handed to the players who met their requirements.
Additionally, the players score points for the individual terrains in their kingdom.  The terrains with the highest number of different symbols generate points, which are then indicated by the scorecards. 
The player with the highest score is the winner.

Note: The Kickstarter edition included both Expansions and Variants expansions.

This is a game in the fortified Roman camp of Haltern. The players are legionaries doing their rounds in the camp. They have different buildings to reach and have to end their round in the principia.
It is a roll, move and remove with with action spaces and individual obstacles.
First to reach the goal wins.

—user summary

Stix (a pun on the Danish "stik", meaning trick) is a Rummy-derivative with missions; players draw cards and discard cards trying to assemble a hand that fulfils their mission, and then close the round before the other players also fulfil their missions.

—user summary

1848: The Golden Spike (aka 1848LT, or "The one true 1862") is a member of the "18xx" series of games.  The series is based on 1829, by Francis Tresham.  1848LT is set in the western part of the US.
Two to six players represent investors in railroad corporations, spending their initial capital to buy wholly-owned Private and Subsidiary Companies and shares in Public Corporations and the Credit Mobilier.

The Public Corporations, each controlled by the largest shareholder (its President), build track and run trains in order to earn revenues.  These can be paid out as dividends to shareholders or retained to fund further track and rolling stock. 
A key feature of 1848LT, as with all the other games in the series, is that the interests of the President and the interests of its shareholders are not identical, so minority shareholders need to be careful in their investments.

Being a President is not without its difficulties, either; bailing out an insolvent Corporation is the sole responsibility of its President.

— user description

City Planner is a 9 cards, 9 cubes, 9 dice version of Town Center mixed with Card City and dice. Your Small City is divided into several blocks that contain different boroughs (Residential, Commerce, Industry, Cultural Buildings, City Hall or mixed zoning of Residential and Commerce).

It is a dice game where you decide where to place/block/affect the dice to get the most money/VP.

During the game players will do the following four phases in order: Rolling Dice, Passing a Card, Scoring All Cards, Turn End.

The game ends after 8 rounds.

Cover artwork by - Ilya Baranovsky

—description from the designer

1 to 3 Players
Deckbuilding - Dice Management - Strategy - Solitary - Cooperative - Competitive

This game incorporates into the world of Experior, not only the Dark Epic Fantasy, already present in other games of the line, but also includes Science Fiction from different evolutionary paradigms, telekinetic developments, steampunk technology, Cyberpunk, worlds of almighty beings, anomalies, mutations and aberrations.

Starting from an asymmetric deck of 10 basic cards, each player will throw basic dice, exchange the cards in their hand for more dice, use their abilities or enhance other abilities already triggered. The combinations of use are infinite and these will depend on what the dice dictate, being able to also get new cards, buy improvements or travel through the portals, taking them to uncertain destinations. There you can fight or find objects or more fissures that will allow you to continue traveling.

In solo mode, the player must close a number of portals, while the automa will take time away from the game. The player has an initial life, if the automa consumes the time or the player's life reaches zero, the player loses.
In competitive mode, it will be a race between players to see who manages to close the portals first.

—description from the designer


1 a 3 Jugadores
Deckbuilding - Gestión de Dados - Estrategia - Solitario - Cooperativo - Competitivo

Los manipuladores de energía  pueden cerrar las fisuras, entrada de los Mitos a nuestro mundo. Para esto deben viajar a través de ellas como portales, llevándolos a destinos desconocidos entre los distintos planos de realidad y sus diferentes líneas temporales.

Este juego incorpora al mundo de Experior, no solo la Fantasía Épica Oscura, ya presente en otros juegos de la linea, sino que incluye la Ciencia Ficción desde distintos paradigmas evolutivos, desarrollos telequinéticos, tecnología steampunk, Ciberpunk, mundos de seres todopoderosos, anomalías, mutaciones y aberraciones.

Partiendo de un mazo asimétrico de 10 cartas básicas, cada jugador arrojara dados básicos, podrá usar las cartas en su mano para canjear por mas dados o usar sus habilidades si puede pagarlas o potenciar otras habilidades ya disparadas. Las combinaciones de uso son infinitas y estas dependerán de lo que los dados dicten, pudiendo aparte conseguir nuevas cartas, comprando mejoras o viajar por los portales, llevándolo a destinos inciertos. Ahí podrá pelear o encontrar objetos o mas fisuras que le permitirán seguir viajando.

En modo solitario, el jugador debe cerrar una cantidad de portales, mientras el automa ira restando tiempo de juego. El jugador tiene una vida inicial, si el automa consume el tiempo o la vida del jugador llega a cero, el jugador pierde. 
En modo competitivo, será una carrera entre los jugadores por ver quien logra cerrar primero los portales.

—description from the designer (Spanish)

Plan, position, and win in this puzzle game of speed and strategy!

In PicTwist: Bob Ross, the scenic landscapes from The Joy of Painting have been scrambled up, appearing upside down, sideways, and out of order. Put your planning skills to the test with Action Cards to race against other players and reconstruct his works of art. Be the first one to correctly restore your painting to win!

Window Pains is a light 2-4 player strategy game where you are a craftsmen building a stained glass window, and your opponents are lowly interns messing it up.

Players add cards, partially overlapping the cards already on the table, and score points for the colors connected to rosettes as the play area slowly grows. At the end of the game, score bonus points for your secret objective and tally points to find the winner!

TuHao is a simple, quick game designed to capture the traditional climbing game experience for two. Tuhao is the Chinese colloquial term for the new class of crass rich folks who have arisen during the past several decades in China.

A game is three hands long. All three hands are dealt to each player at the beginning, but not revealed until each round begins. In each round, the aim is get rid of all your cards first by playing combos. Each time a player “passes” because they are unable or unwilling to play a higher combo, that passing player purloins two cards from the previous played combo to re-use next hand--one card for them and the other for their opponent.

As players start each new round they combine the cards dealt at the beginning with the “tribute” cards chosen or allotted from the previous round.  At the end of each round players score for the number of cards left in their opponent’s hand, and at the end of the three rounds the winner is the player with the highest total points.

This game is called Murder Mystery. The player becomes one of the characters in the story and searches for the culprit of the incident that occurs in the story. Since the criminal is also one of the players, the purpose is that the player who became the criminal does not know that he is the criminal.
Each player has his or her own purpose other than searching for the criminal or not knowing it, and each player aims to achieve multiple goals and win the points obtained by achieving them.

"Ronaena -Gift of Disaster-" is a story about searching for the murderer of the murder case that occurs at the research school facility "Ronaena" in the near future in 2025.

—description from the designer

This game is called Murder Mystery. The player becomes one of the characters in the story and searches for the culprit of the incident that occurs in the story. Since the criminal is also one of the players, the purpose is that the player who became the criminal does not know that he is the criminal.
Each player has his or her own purpose other than searching for the criminal or not knowing it, and each player aims to achieve multiple goals and win the points obtained by achieving them.

"Ricca To Haiiro No Tsukimisou -Ricca and Gray Cherry Blossoms-" is the first in a series of Murder mystery that seeks out the true criminal by clearing the suspicion of the girl detective "Ricca" who is always the suspect in the case.

Find out the truth about the fall and death of her students in Ricca's high school.

—description from the designer

Naivety and ingenuity are shared.

Una Que Pensamos Todes is a game of associations. A game that proposes to discover the corners of our minds that we share with the rest. Once per round, a person will turn over a card from the Context Deck and a card from the Trigger deck at the same time. Each player will then have one minute to think or write down a concept or idea that associates both cards. After the minute we will see how many people put the same thing as us and that will be our score. After ten rounds, whoever has scored the most points will be the person who wins.

Ryozen is a 2-4 player worker placement game with a layered rotating board and multiple scoring and resources engines, set in a fantasy world of mystical forces and animals with extraordinary abilities.

It's a busy time in the kingdom of Ryozen! Like all the others, your clan has assembled the most skilled kin who can perform various tasks and bring you the honors you deserve. These are the final nights, when you can prove that your clan is the most capable of doing good for the kingdom. The Phoenix Queen is about to awaken in her mountaintop palace, which you can rotate to gain special benefits from the nearby lands. Seize the moment and do your best to obtain her favor!

In Ryozen the contention is always at a high pace with both direct and indirect interaction between players. The board, flippable for a two player setup, is divided into sectors that provide different sets of possible actions, but only for a limited number of available placements.

Secure the best places for your kin to gather or manage resources, recruit more allies with asymmetrical abilities, influence the tie-breaker and collect cards to improve your strategy. The turn flow runs smoothly from the very beginning, with immediate placement effects during the day phase and global effects resolved sector by sector during the night.

Never lose sight of your rivals and strive for the highest prestige!

—description from the publisher

In this fast-paced game, players must solve a word or dexterity challenge before the bomb explodes! In addition to word challenges similar to the classic 'Pass the Bomb' game, this Family edition for 3 to 8 players adds simple skill/dexterity challenges like catching a ball in a cup or quickly 'building' a worm out of puzzle pieces. The word challenge categories are 'Word Acrobat', 'Rhyming Artist', and 'Typical' (thematically-related words). The 'bomb' is an electronic ticking timer that can 'explode' with no warning during the game.

—user summary

Unlock! is a cooperative card game inspired by escape rooms that uses a simple system which allows you to search scenes, combine objects, and solve riddles. Play Unlock! to embark on great adventures, while seated at a table using only cards and a companion app that can provide clues, check codes, monitor time remaining, etc.

Unlock! Game Adventures includes three separate scenarios for you to explore, each set in a different well-known board games universe:


     Mysterium: Enter the manor and experience a dark and surreal investigation in which you must resolve the murder with the Ghost's vision cards in a dreamlike and esoteric journey filled with mysteries...
     Ticket to Ride: Take a train trip across the U.S. in which you must thwart the scheme planned by the Rail Barons.
     Pandemic:  An epidemic threatens humankind! Everyone's future depends on you and your team of medical experts (virologist, medic, dispatcher...) as you face a global health crisis.


Note: Unlock! requires a free application to be downloaded from the App Store or Google Play. Once downloaded, an internet connection is not required during game play.

—description from the publisher

Postaw na klocka is a board game in which players try to construct the building shown on the card as quickly as possible. Some of them are individual challenges, but most of them require you to join teams temporarily with the players indicated by the card. You should demonstrate not only dexterity here, but also good communication and perceptiveness, because the buildings must be constructed according to the pattern and color. The fastest player or team gets one point each.

When a player's pawn stands on a special field, he must draw a difficulty card. From that moment on, he must play a given grasping technique, e.g. using only his thumbs or not bending his elbow.

Have you ever wanted to understand why healthcare expenses are one of the leading causes of bankruptcies in the US in a fun educational way that also lets you destroy your friends? No? Well too bad, this game exists.

The goal of the game is to avoid getting the Bankruptcy cards. You have everything in your arsenal from GoFundMe campaigns, private equity buyouts, and PBMs to make sure you're the last one to go bankrupt. Discover all the insane ways the healthcare system ends up making you pay while getting distracted by the cute illustrations that describe them. Non-US citizens will not understand this game at all.

—description from the designer

Fiesta de Los Juegos is a special edition adapted from Fiesta de los Muertos. Instead of finding deceased celebrities, you'll have to find board game names. This very limited edition celebrates the board game industry and was sold at the French game event Festival des Jeux de Cannes 2022.

Each player chooses a word to describe their starting board game themed card. But beware, this word will pass from hand to hand, and change little by little. Indeed, each turn players will read the clue word written by their neighbour, erase it and write another word related to that clue for the next player around the table. Looking at the final words after they have been passed and altered four times and the starting cards, will everyone be able to find the right connections?

Boat Canasta is the fast-moving card game where teams score points by melding cards (combining at least 3 or more cards of the same rank). The goal of the game is for each team to create at least one Canasta, or meld of seven cards, in each round. Teams work in unison, and their luck can change depending on how the cards fall. Point values are printed directly on the cards for easy scoring.

To score the most points by creating Melds, Canastas  and earning bonuses. The first team to reach 10,000 points wins the game. If both teams reach a score of  10,000 points in the same round, then the team with the most points wins. For a shorter game, players can  agree on a lower point total before play begins, say 5,000 points.

The forces of darkness have pushed all the way south, destroying everything in their path. The city of Lux is all that stands in their way from completely overtaking the realm. A small group of heroes must work together to fend off the evil army long enough to take out its leader.

The Last Stronghold is a dice-driven siege game in which you must fend off monsters in the areas surrounding Lux and prevent them from overtaking the city. You use special abilities and magical artifacts to manipulate the dice and monsters, with the goal of eventually taking out the final boss...should you last long enough. On your turn, you add threats to the board, decide which threats you want to deal with, move to that location, roll dice and use hero abilities to get rid of those threats, and repeat until you either defeat the final boss OR all heroes are incapacitated OR the main city you're protecting takes too much damage.

—description from the publisher

FLOAT: From the Deep is a fast-paced tabletop game where players find themselves lost at sea, battling monsters from below and attempting to outsmart and outlast their fellow survivors. With only 7 days to make it to the island in the foggy distance, it’s sink, swim, or be devoured by the next creature from the deep.

Players draw and play cards, roll dice for battling, and manage their resources and crew through their player stations. The game ends when either all members but one have been eliminated, or once all surviving parties make it to the island. They have 7 days (21 rounds) to clear and make it to the island or become shark bait.

Players win by surviving the terrors from the deep and making it safely to the island.

A Card Game for the Normal Mormon This is essentially a edgy Mormon version of Cards against Humanity. Or in a more Mormon speaking way, a edgy version of Apples to Apples.

Draw a tan card, everybody picks one black card from their hand and you pick the best answer.  First to 5 points wins.

Roll a die at the beginning of your turn, if you roll a 6, draw a card and preform it's action. you can also try to inflict a Lucifer card on another player.

In Space Rocket, you are all part of a company that is looking for a way out of space and close to the Moon. Growing fuel, generating fuel, capacity and training.

Includes 3 game modes: cooperative, solitary and competitive.

The game box is placed upside-down in the center of the tab. le and on it, the Take-Off card and the Space Rocket. Players start with 10 Fuel tokens. Shuffle all the folded cards (Light Blue Sky, Blue Sky and Outer Space). Also shuffle the 10 Grey Cloud cards with the Moon card below them.

Each turn, players must use a Fuel token, place 2 folded cards vertically without touching the rocket and then a Grey Clouds card above them. Finally, they must take the Space Rocket and put it above the card. If it touches a resource, take it. If it touches an Acceleration arrow, repeat your turn.

The objective of the game is to reach the Moon with 5 or more coins left.
Players lose if the tower of cards fall off or they run out of fuel.

For competitive play, the winner is the one with most coins when the last card is played or the cards fall (who makes it fall loses all their coins).

In Kingyo, you have to catch as many Kingyo (goldfishes) as possible, matching the colors of the dice.

The Kingyo cards are laid out around the 5 dice. Players can divide themselves into teams as they wish. Each player takes a Bowl card to place the Kingyo cards they will catch.

One player rolls the 5 dice, then all players simultaneously try to catch the cards with Kingyo that match the colors of the dice, announcing the colors of the Kingyo caught.

Some cards have bonuses in addition to the Kingyo:
If you catch a Dragonfly, roll all 5 dice again.
If you catch a Hornet, each opponent must discard a card from their bowl.
If you catch a Scoop, you can immediately take any card.

When you think it's no longer possible to catch Kingyo cards with colors that match the dice, catch one of the special "Medaka" cards.  The game is over for you, but other players can continue to catch cards if they find any. Be careful because there is one less Medaka card than the number of players...

At the end of the game, players score 1 point for each Kingyo and 4 points for the Medaka card in their bowl. In a team game, only the team's bowl with the lowest score will count.

- description from designers

Album is a cooperative game in which players have to correctly identify a picture among 5 others. To do so, the active player gives an intensity to concepts received by their partners. With each new word added, the players rule one picture out. Watch out, what is obvious for you might be puzzling for the others!

A new King of Game rises: King of Monster Island

We have detected irregular movement on the Monster Island. The volcano is erupting like never before. Monsters from all around the world are gathering on the Island, what is happening? They don’t even fight each other anymore!
Because is a greater menace is lurking. Something big enough to threaten every monster and make them fight together against the same enemy…

Was this in the script? Wait… Is this a cooperative King of game?

In King of Monster Island, players will play as giant monsters who must work together to defeat a titan-like Boss before it finishes building an interdimensional portal. Each turn, players will roll dice to damage minions & boss, heal themselves, gain energy and buy cards, move around the island, activate human support, and increase fame. For the Boss’ actions, they are controlled entirely by the game itself. Using the results of the dice rolled into the volcano, the Boss will move, activate their minions, and attack nearby monsters. 
Their goal: allow their minions to set up the pylons needed to construct the portal. To win, the players must defeat the Boss before they manage to activate the portal or defeat even a single Monster.

Otherwise Earth will be demolished!

—description from the publisher

The Aeronautica Imperialis: Wrath of Angels boxed set includes everything you need to play exciting games of aerial combat between brutal Adeptus Astartes and sleek Asuryani aircraft.

The set includes the following Citadel multipart plastic miniatures, each supplied with an Aeronautica Imperialis base:

3x Adeptus Astartes Xiphon Interceptors
2x Adeptus Astartes Storm Eagles
3x Asuryani Nightwings
3x Asuryani Phoenix Bombers

The set also includes a 38-page rulebook featuring the following information:

The full Aeronautica Imperialis game rules, including how to build your force using Squadron Lists, perform Ace Manoeuvres, field different classes of aircraft, and unleash ground defences. Learn how to manoeuvre your aircraft, adjust their altitude, and change speed while avoiding the risks of stalling and breaking up. There are even rules for special manoeuvres including landing, taxiing, and taking off.


     The Dogfight scenario, as well as optional rules for fighting at night or in bad weather conditions.  
     Squadron Lists, providing details of all of the aircraft in the box as well as their weapon options and special rules.
     A reference page showing the 8 different manoeuvres aircraft can take, as well as a 2-page quick-reference guide containing the key game rules. 
     Wrath of Angels Starter Scenarios Booklet (including 3 additional scenarios to play)
     Duble-sided Area of Engagement game mat (depicting two aerial war zones)
     Quick-reference cards (containing the key game rules)

Mini case (22 cards) of Unlock.  Given out at the 2021 Lucca Games & Comics show in the "Bag of Lucca".

Can you solve the mystery of the Stone Phantom?


All thieves dream of getting their hands on the Trivoc, a most precious stone. Lord Victor Beckett, it’s former owner, used to keep it in the safe of his Devon’s country house, which he has haunted since his demise. Therefore, no one but you, the most daring team of thieves in the country, would dare to enter. Slip into the mansion and steal the gem.

This 25-card exclusive demo adventure will allow you to learn Unlock! quickly and without reading the rules.

Unlock! is a cooperative card game inspired by escape rooms that uses a simple system which allows you to search scenes, combine objects, and solve riddles. Play Unlock! to embark on great adventures, while seated at a table using only cards and a companion app that can provide clues, check codes, monitor time remaining, etc.

Note: Unlock! requires a free application to be downloaded from the App Store or Google Play. Once downloaded, an internet connection is not required during game play.

Fluxx Remixx is a card game in which the cards themselves determine the current rules of the game. By playing cards, you change numerous aspects of the game: how to draw cards, how to play cards, and even how to win.

At the start of the game, each player holds three cards and on a turn a player draws one card, then plays one card. By playing cards, you can put new rules into play that change numerous aspects of the game: how many cards to draw or play, how many cards you can hold in hand or keep on the table in front of you, and (most importantly) how to win the game.

Fluxx Remixx uses all the Keepers from regular Fluxx, but everything else is re-imagined, with a new set of Goals using different combinations of Keepers, along with new Rules, Actions, and Surprises.

It's Halloween, and it's time to go trick-or-treating!

The aim of the game is to get as much candy as you can, while running away from grumpy neighbors. The game consists of 13 dice — 12 white (treat) dice and 1 orange (trick) die. There are 6 different kinds of candy to collect that fall into 3 types; chocolate, lollipop or gummy.

A player's turn involves repeating two phases — rolling and collecting — until all the dice are set aside. When the dice are rolled, you must first set aside all Grumps. You can then choose any number of Runs to set aside, keeping in mind if there are more Grumps than Runs at the end of your turn, you get 0 points. You then choose any amount of one kind of candy to collect, each worth one point. On the orange die, a Double Trouble must be set aside and requires two Runs to escape. Tricks are worth nothing and can be re-rolled. If you roll a Mystery Candy, you choose at the end of your turn which candy it represents, as different combinations of collected candy get you bonus points!

The first person to get 23 points triggers the end of the game, and the person with the most points at the end of that round wins.

—description from the publisher

Bad Aim isn’t your regular “sit around a table” adult board game. It’s a WTF-just-happened, unpredictable action game for adults where two teams race to shoot down targets that contain outrageous challenge cards. The first team to shoot down their targets wins, while the losing team is forced to complete the challenges left standing. Bottom line? Those with bad aim will be shamed. This adult party game will have you questioning your friends’ sanity, and quite possibly, all of humanity.

—description from the publisher

Rainbow River is a grid-movement tableau-building game where players compete to get the most resources from an ever-changing board, with a unique setup for each game. Players play as explorers trying to piece together a cohesive map of the mystical rainbow river and fighting over map scraps.

You start with a randomized board and a unique Preference card. As the game develops, the board will shrink, and players will attempt to collect map tiles that will advance their river.

Build the longest river in order to secure victory!

—description from the designer

In this game emotions, tension, but also joy and well-being await you, just as you like it during real races. In the game you will start training the physical and mental qualities of your jumper. You will manage its energy, which will be important in racing. Of course, you will jump from a ski jumping hill with a realistic-looking jumper figure. 
As in real jumps, you will solve not only the length of the jump, but also the style and point evaluation of the judges. Your jumps will also be affected by the wind and also the equipment in which you will jump. 
The aim of the game is to place as best as possible in the individual races of the cup tour and become its overall winner.

At the beginning, each player slides the jumper's figure from the hill, and based on the distance determined by the rollers, we determine the order in which the player's cards are selected. Each of them have certain predispositions such as psyche, speed, technique, etc. Once we have chosen the player's card, we go to choose the flag of which nationality you want to represent. There is also a card draw on which hill we will jump. They are shuffled, then turn. So let's say it's going to be Japan, for example. This card is placed on the 3D hill and indicates to us what nation we jump in. Based on that, the home jumpers will benefit from a better meters rating simulating crowd support. And then the size of the hill is randomly selected by turning over the top card of the bridge and finding out that we are racing on the K90 hill, for example. Then we can go into the training of our ski jumper (players cards). Based on the different predispositions of individual jumpers, we can improve individual training skills, which happens in specialized rooms in gyms on the board and therefore we can choose which ability we want to improve. They are on special cards. This gains points on the player's card, but we lose time and energy while we train. And as we lose time, we gradually get closer to the day of the race, and as soon as we get to the seventh day, we can go jump from the hill. Before the race starts and we go jumping, we calculate the points we have gathered in training and then we will find it on the spinner table. According to the hill on which the race is held. And if we had the same nationality as the flag on the hill, we would get more bonus meters. Which is like fans support us. So, after entering the values, you can jump. Jumping is made by putting your plastic figure down from the hill. At the edge of the hill there are two rollers which are triggered by the plastic figure and there have plus and minus symbol and numbers. These rollers simulate so-called random weather factor such as the Wind, or the current mental state of the jumper, etc. If we jumped +1 point. We will write down all those things in a notebook and in the final evaluation of the jump, in addition to the points gained in training, the place where the jumper finished will also be recorded. We have different point areas. The possibility of falling is incorporated into the game. If the jumper does not reach the point area or fall, he will not get any points. But he also has another way to get points for style as in real, and these are the cards that represent the points we know from ski jumping. The points work by dealing 5 cards to the player, he does not look at them. Another five cards are dealt in front of him, and after turning the hourglass, which has a limit of 30 seconds, the player tries to find the best possible numbers in order to get the best points for style. After matching the cards, the highest and the lowest value is deleted, as it works in real races. The remaining three values â€‹â€‹on the cards are summed up and written down in a notebook. All entered values â€‹â€‹are then summed up on a special designed notebook so you don't have to remember all you data and the winner gets one of the trophies.

—description from the publisher

ENTER THE DEADZONE

Deadzone takes place in containment zones – cities or whole planets that have been erased from planetary maps and left for dead. You control an elite team of soldiers ready to enter the potentially lethal Deadzone and scavenge for whatever lucrative resources you can find. But competition is fierce, and other Strike Teams will be out to thwart you on your mission. Get in, get out, get rich, or get dead.

CINEMATIC, IMMERSIVE GAMEPLAY

Deadzone uses an innovative cube-based system for movement and shooting. Throw your tape measures in the garbage because you’re never going to need them again! Apart from DIY, of course. Models can be moved anywhere in a cube, which ensures you can make the best use of cover and obstacles to avoid the enemy, and movement takes seconds, rather than minutes. Shooting is just the same – measure the distance in cubes and, if you can see it, you can shoot it! Wargaming has never been this fast or cinematic.

MORE THAN 5 YEARS OF RULES DEVELOPMENT

Since the release of Deadzone: Second Edition in 2016, we’ve been refining the rules to make them faster and more streamlined. Third Edition incorporates all the changes and improvements made in the previous Outbreak and Escalation supplements, along with a host of other refinements. This is the Deadzone you love… just better. If you’ve never played before… well you’ve just found your new favourite game.

—description from the publisher
